Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Geographic variation in Dmrt1 in the North American green frog
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal investigates the processes that determine if an embryo becomes a male or female. These processes can differ widely among species, but other features are more conserved between species. Previous work by the researchers showed that the North American green frog and humans share portions of the genome that are important for determining whether an embryo becomes a male or female. Importantly, the researchers discovered that the gene DMRT1, which is critical for human male gonads to develop as normal testes, is also important in green frog development. The researchers also noted widespread abnormalities in green frog development in suburban neighborhoods. This might indicate that human-derived contaminants interfere with how frogs develop. That work was conducted on green frogs in Connecticut. However, green frogs range across half of the United States and parts of Canada, and variation occurs across that range. In addition, work in one European and one Japanese frog species shows variation among populations across the species' range. This project will study the genomic variation in the gene DMRT1 and other genomics regions linked to development in green frogs across the United States. This project will substantially advance our understanding of how variable the genetic basis of development is across a large geographic area. It will also begin to show the extent to which environmental conditions across the country impact frog development. The work will be distributed to the public in a variety of ways including online blogs and guest lectures for K-12 teachers.

Using tissue samples collected from male and female green frogs from representative regions across the species' range, the researchers will test for geographic variation in allele frequencies and linkage for DMRT1. Additionally, the researchers will test whether a set of genetic markers shown to be linked with particular chromosomes specific to males and females are similarly linked across the species range. Geographic areas with varying degrees of this linkage, either for DMRT1 or the other markers, will indicate regions of the species' range where environmental conditions are more likely to influence the processes driving whether an embryo becomes male or female.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The manner in which an individual’s sex is determined varies dramatically throughout the animal kingdom. In mammals and birds, whether an individual develops as a female or a male is tightly controlled by genetic differences. In many turtles and fishes as well as all crocodilians, the temperature at which an embryo is raised explicitly determines the sexual fate of an individual. However, in many taxa, an individual’s phenotypic sex is the result of interactions between a predisposed genetic sex and different environmental conditions. This is the case with amphibians.

 

Because amphibian sex is the product to innate mechanisms and environmental influences, it has generally remained challenging to study the genetic basis of sex in any of the almost 8,000 amphibian species. Furthermore, the sex chromosome system (e.g., XX-XY as in mammals or ZZ-ZW as in birds) has changed dozens of times throughout amphibian evolutionary history. Emerging evidence has similarly begun to reveal that not only does the genetic basis of sex vary wildly among amphibian species but it also can vary substantially among populations of the same species.

 

The work here builds upon prior research on sex determination in the green frog (Rana clamitans), a species with a large range across the eastern and central United States and parts of Canada. By studying green frog populations in southern Connecticut, we previously identified sex-linked regions of the green frog genome which show genetic coding differences between females and males. Our new results show that these same genomic regions are not as tightly linked to sex in other areas of Connecticut and are not sex-linked at all across the rest of the species’ range in North America. Additionally, we found that sex-reversed genetic males (i.e., genetic males that develop as females) regularly breed in wild green frog populations in southern Connecticut. In addition to demonstrating that sex-reversed frogs can freely breed, sex-reversed XY-females also enhance the exchange of genetic material between X- and Y- chromosomes. When the X- and Y- chromosomes exchange genetic material frequently enough, it can reduce how tightly associated genetic variants on sex chromosomes are with one sex or another. Breeding by sex-reversed genetic males perhaps presents one mechanism by which sex-linked genomic loci identified in one area of the species’ range are less sex-linked elsewhere.

 

These results demonstrate that the genetic basis of sex in green frogs is labile across its range in North America and that breeding by sex-reversed adults likely contributes to the sexual diversity of this species. This work opens up future avenues of research in Unites States for understanding the geographic variation both in the genetic basis of sex in amphibians as well as the sensitivity of sex to different environmental conditions.
